Which one of the following screening tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A urine creatinine concentration can serve as a reference when measured with another substance in the urine. When the urine creatinine is very high on a random sample, the urine is highly concentrated. When the urine creatinine is low, the specimen is dilute. This test does not provide any information regarding diabetic nephropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

The gold standard for measurement of urine protein is a 24-hour urine total protein test, but it is burdensome, and mistakes in collection are common.

C) CORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus and hypertension are the leading causes of end-stage renal disease. Screening for albuminuria is crucial for identifying diabetic nephropathy early and is recommended for three groups: patients who have had type 1 diabetes for at least 5 years, patients who have type 1 diabetes and comorbid hypertension, and all patients with type 2 diabetes.

The best screening test for diabetic nephropathy is a spot urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio. Both moderate and severe albuminuria (defined by a urinary albumin excretion of 30 to 300 mg/day and >300 mg/day, respectively) are associated with a decline in kidney function and increased mortality. Early recognition of albuminuria may prompt a change in care or the addition of an agent to block the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis.

Urine albumin is a more sensitive marker for diabetic kidney disease than urine protein. The urine albumin test is performed as an immunoassay and can detect minute amounts of urine albumin that are above the threshold for normal but below the threshold for the urinary dipstick. This test also includes the urine creatinine level to account for whether the specimen is concentrated or dilute.

Key learning point: A sensitive screening test for detecting early diabetic kidney disease is measurement of urine albumin.

D) INCORRECT:

The urine protein concentration is not useful because it may be normal if the urine is very dilute and high if the urine is very concentrated. The gold standard for measurement of urine protein is a 24-hour urine total protein test, but it is burdensome, and mistakes in collection are common.

E) INCORRECT:

Although dipstick urinalysis can detect urine protein, it is not recommended as a screening test in this clinical context because it is not sufficiently sensitive to detect the low urine protein concentrations seen in patients with early diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease stage 3B presents for routine follow-up. He reports that he has been doing well overall with respect to diet and exercise and that he checks his blood glucose levels every morning; they have averaged 103 mg/dL since his last visit, with no hypoglycemic events. His current medications include metformin 1000 mg twice daily, insulin glargine 24 units nightly, lisinopril 40 mg daily, and rosuvastatin 40 mg daily.
On physical examination, his blood pressure is 123/81 mm Hg, his heart rate is 74 beats per minute, his temperature is 36.7°C, and his oxygen saturation is 98% while he breathes ambient air. His heart rhythm sounds are regular, his lungs are clear, and there is no lower-extremity edema.
Laboratory testing shows a serum creatinine level of 2.34 mg/dL (reference range, 0.8–1.3) and an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 34 mL/min/1.73 m2 (≥60). The glycated hemoglobin level is 6.8% and has been stable for the past year. The urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio is 538 mg/g (<30).
Which one of the following medication changes is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Reduce the dose of insulin glargine to 10 units nightly

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and proteinuria who are already taking an angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor or angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB), the addition of a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor has been shown to reduce the incidence of both CKD progression and all-cause mortality, regardless of the presence or absence of type 2 diabetes. SGLT-2 inhibitors have been shown to be safe and effective in patients with CKD who have an estimated glomerular filtration rate >25 mL/min/1.73 m2 and a urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio of 200 to 5000 mg/g. This patient meets these criteria and should have an SGLT-2 inhibitor added to his regimen.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a patient with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes who has persistent proteinuria while taking an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor or angiotensin-receptor blocker is to start a sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitor.

B) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors and ARBs are both effective in reducing the progression of kidney disease in patients with severely increased albuminuria (≥300 mg/day). Switching from an ACE inhibitor to an ARB would not be expected to lead to any significant improvement in such patients.

C) INCORRECT:

A slight (10%–20%) reduction in insulin dose is reasonable when another antidiabetic agent, such as an SGLT-2 inhibitor, is started in a patient who already has good glycemic control. However, in the absence of hypoglycemic events, a dose reduction from 24 units to 10 units is too much and would be expected to lead to worse glycemic control, which would in turn increase the risk of progression of kidney disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists, such as spironolactone, appear to reduce albuminuria and may reduce progression of CKD, but they have not been shown to reduce mortality and may carry an increased risk of hyperkalemia when combined with an ACE inhibitor or ARB.

E) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors and ARBs are both effective in reducing the progression of kidney disease in patients with severely increased albuminuria (≥300 mg/day). Combining an ACE inhibitor with an ARB has not been shown to provide benefit in slowing the progression of kidney disease and may lead to more harm — as well as adverse events such as hyperkalemia.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the office because of a 3-month history of fatigue and weakness. Her hemoglobin A1c concentration was 13.5% 12 weeks ago. Her blood pressure is 152/92 mm Hg. Examination shows lower extremity edema. Serum studies show:


K+

5.1 mEq/L


Phosphorus
5.0 mg/dL


Ca2+

7.8 mg/dL


Urea nitrogen
60 mg/dL


Creatinine
2.2 mg/dL


Which of the following is the most appropriate parameter for early detection of this patient’s renal condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of urinary red blood cell casts indicates glomerulonephritis (GN). This finding is caused by the congregation of proteins and RBCs inside the tubules. Clinically, GN can result in red or cola-colored urine, mild edema (due to the relatively limited loss of albumin), and hypertension (i.e., nephritic syndrome). However, diabetic nephropathy classically leads to nephrotic syndrome, not nephritic syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Diabetic nephropathy leads to nephrotic syndrome, which typically manifests with hypoproteinemia. However, total protein is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only decreases once there is significant glomerular damage.

C) CORRECT:

Microalbuminuria is the earliest diagnostic sign of diabetic nephropathy. Progression of glomerular damage (nodular glomerulosclerosis) leads to increased urinary loss of albumin, which can manifest as nephrotic syndrome. The extent of albuminuria in patients with diabetic nephropathy also correlates with the risk of future cardiovascular events. ACE inhibitors can prevent the progression of albuminuria in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum urea nitrogen (BUN) is routinely measured as part of renal function testing in patients with diabetic nephropathy and other forms of chronic kidney disease. However, BUN is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only rises once the glomerular filtration rate significantly deteriorates.

E) INCORRECT:

Serum creatinine is routinely measured as part of renal function testing in patients with diabetic nephropathy and other forms of chronic kidney disease. However, it is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only rises once the glomerular filtration rate significantly deteriorates.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents with features of diabetic nephropathy (elevated creatinine and BUN levels, arterial hypertension, electrolyte abnormalities, edema).

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman comes to the office for a follow-up examination. She feels well. She has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. A retinal examination from 2 years ago showed evidence of mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 54 kg (119 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin A1c

8.4%


Serum



Glucose
190 mg/dL


Urea nitrogen
22 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


Urinalysis shows 2+ protein and increased urinary albumin excretion. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the initiation of this patient's renal disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glycosuria occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus when blood glucose levels exceed renal tubular reabsorption capacity (typically when blood glucose levels are above 180 mg/dL). While glycosuria is an important risk factor for urinary tract infections, it is not associated with the initiation or progression of DN.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperreninemia plays a significant role as the initiator of pathological renal changes in hypertensive nephropathy. In DN, paracrine hyperreninemia and RAAS activation (secondary to altered glomerular structure and hemodynamics) lead to a vicious cycle that contributes to the progression of DN. Therefore, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers, which have a renoprotective effect independent of the degree of blood-pressure reduction, are used to limit the progression of DN. However, the role of hyperreninemia in the initiation of DN is less clear; normotensive patients with diabetes mellitus often have low or normal levels of plasma renin activity prior to the onset of DN. A different pathophysiological process is the primary initiator of glomerular changes of DN.

C) INCORRECT:

Albuminuria is an early sign of DN and is used as a clinical marker to detect the onset and grade the severity of DN. However, the filtered albumin does not lead to glomerular damage, and albuminuria occurs only when the glomerular filtration capacity is already impaired.

D) CORRECT:

Hyperglycemia is the most significant risk factor for the initiation and progression of DN. Nonenzymatic glycation of proteins occurs in a hyperglycemic environment and results in the formation of advanced glycation end-products and reactive oxygen species, which activate intercellular signaling pathways that lead to epigenetic alterations of proinflammatory and profibrotic gene expression. In the kidneys, this process manifests with thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, progressive glomerular hypertrophy, and glomerulosclerosis, resulting in worsening of the filtration capacity and possibly end-stage renal disease. Glycemic control early in the course of diabetes mellitus has been shown to limit the initiation and progression of DN independent of glycemic control later on (legacy effect). Stringent glycemic control may even partially reverse the loss of glomerular function.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney autopsy specimen (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Nodular glomerulosclerosis in diabetic nephropathy (Kimmelstiel-Wilson syndrome) displays with mesangial thickening due to nodular, hyaline deposits (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions; yellow overlay) within the glomerulus (blue overlay). Further findings include thickening of the tubular basement membranes, tubular atrophy, and an increase of interstitial connective tissue between renal tubules (interstitial fibrosis).

Nodular glomerulosclerosis takes a decade or longer to develop in diabetes mellitus.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

Hyperinsulinemia occurs early in the course of type 2 diabetes mellitus as a result of insulin resistance. Although hyperinsulinemia may lead to renal damage via several mechanisms, it is not the most significant risk factor for the initiation of DN, since DN also occurs in type 1 diabetes mellitus in which patients are hypoinsulinemic.
Image Description:

Early in the disease, there is an increase in β-cell function and insulin production as the body compensates for elevated glucose levels due to increasing insulin resistance. With time, compensatory mechanisms fail and β-cell insulin production falls, resulting in a steady increase in both post-meal and fasting glucose levels. Complications occur as a result of elevated blood glucose levels. Macrovascular complications can occur throughout the disease course, whereas microvascular complications typically occur after years of hyperglycemia.
questions.hint: Proteinuria with increased urinary albumin excretion in a patient with long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus is suggestive of diabetic nephropathy (DN).

questions.text:
A 57-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presents for routine follow-up. Her current medications include metformin, aspirin, chlorthalidone, and atorvastatin. Blood pressure is 151/92 mm Hg, pulse is 59/min, and BMI is 30 kg/m2. Physical examination is notable only for trace bilateral pretibial edema. Laboratory findings include the following levels:


Serum



 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


 Sodium
139 mEq/L


 Potassium
4.0 mEq/L


 Bicarbonate
22 mEq/L


Hemoglobin A1c

6.5 %


The urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio is 324 mg/g (N < 30). In addition to lifestyle modifications, such as weight loss and a low-sodium diet, which of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has adequate glycemic control (as indicated by a glycated hemoglobin level <7%), but her blood pressure (BP) is elevated at 151/92 mm Hg despite treatment. Uncontrolled hypertension and poor glycemic control are the primary risk factors for diabetic nephropathy.

In patients with an elevated BP who have elevated albuminuria, therapy with an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor or an angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB) is recommended over other antihypertensive drugs.

Key learning point: The two most important modifiable risk factors for progression of diabetic nephropathy are hyperglycemia and hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

An increase in metformin is not indicated for this patient given that her glycated hemoglobin level is currently <7%.

C) INCORRECT:

In patients with an elevated BP who have elevated albuminuria, therapy with an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor or an angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB) is recommended over other antihypertensive drugs. Adding the ACE inhibitor lisinopril to this patient’s regimen is therefore a better choice than adding metoprolol.

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with an elevated BP who have elevated albuminuria, therapy with an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor or an angiotensin-receptor blocker (ARB) is recommended over other antihypertensive drugs. Adding the ACE inhibitor lisinopril to this patient’s regimen is therefore a better choice than increasing the dose of chlorthalidone.

E) INCORRECT:

Supplemental bicarbonate is appropriate for patients with evidence of a metabolic acidosis in advanced chronic kidney disease to delay the need for dialysis, but it is not indicated in this patient.
questions.hint: A target BP of < 130/80 mm Hg is recommended in patients with diabetes mellitus.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents for reassessment of type 2 diabetes, which is currently managed with metformin. She also has hyperlipidemia and takes atorvastatin. Temperature is 36.3°C (97,3°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 127/75 mm Hg. Her weight is 93 kg, and her BMI is 32 kg/m2. Nondilated funduscopic examination is normal. The remainder of the physical examination discloses no abnormalities. Laboratory findings include the following levels:


Fasting glucose
183 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


Blood urea nitrogen
18 mg/dL


Estimated glomerular filtration rate

≥ 60 mL/min/1.73 m2 (N ≥ 60)


Glycated hemoglobin
7.6%


Which one of the following screening tests is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A urine creatinine concentration can serve as a reference when measured with another substance in the urine. When the urine creatinine is very high on a random sample, the urine is highly concentrated. When the urine creatinine is low, the specimen is dilute. This test does not provide any information regarding diabetic nephropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

The gold standard for measurement of urine protein is a 24-hour urine total protein test, but it is burdensome, and mistakes in collection are common.

C) CORRECT:

Diabetes mellitus and hypertension are the leading causes of end-stage renal disease. Screening for albuminuria is crucial for identifying diabetic nephropathy early and is recommended for three groups: patients who have had type 1 diabetes for at least 5 years, patients who have type 1 diabetes and comorbid hypertension, and all patients with type 2 diabetes. The best screening test for diabetic nephropathy is a spot urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio. Both moderate and severe albuminuria (defined by a urinary albumin excretion of 30 to 300 mg/day and >300 mg/day, respectively) are associated with a decline in kidney function and increased mortality. Early recognition of albuminuria may prompt a change in care or the addition of an agent to block the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis.

Urine albumin is a more sensitive marker for diabetic kidney disease than urine protein. The urine albumin test is performed as an immunoassay and can detect minute amounts of urine albumin that are above the threshold for normal but below the threshold for the urinary dipstick. This test also includes the urine creatinine level to account for whether the specimen is concentrated or dilute.

Key learning point: A sensitive screening test for detecting early diabetic kidney disease is measurement of urine albumin.

D) INCORRECT:

The urine protein concentration is not useful because it may be normal if the urine is very dilute and high if the urine is very concentrated. The gold standard for measurement of urine protein is a 24-hour urine total protein test, but it is burdensome, and mistakes in collection are common.

E) INCORRECT:

Although dipstick urinalysis can detect urine protein, it is not recommended as a screening test in this clinical context because it is not sufficiently sensitive to detect the low urine protein concentrations seen in patients with early diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-month history of fatigue and increased urination. The patient reports that he has been drinking more than usual because he is constantly thirsty. He has intermittent episodes of blurred vision. He had elevated blood pressure at his previous visit but is otherwise healthy. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 93 kg (205 lb); BMI is 29 kg/m2. His pulse is 75/min and his blood pressure is 144/94 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin A1c
7.1%


Serum



 Glucose
220 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


 Total cholesterol
270 mg/dL


Urine



 Glucose
2+


 Albumin:creatinine ratio


280 mg/g (N < 30)


In addition to metformin therapy and counseling for lifestyle modifications, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: No additional management is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

All patients with T2DM aged 40–75 years should receive lipid-lowering treatment regardless of baseline lipid levels to reduce the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. However, statins are the first-line therapy, not fibrates. Fibrates are used in the treatment of severe hypertriglyceridemia.

B) INCORRECT:

Insulin therapy should be considered in patients with newly diagnosed T2DM who present with symptoms of hyperglycemia (as seen here), signs of a continued catabolic state (e.g., weight loss), initial glucose ≥ 300 mg/dL, or HbA1c > 10%. However, a basal insulin regimen with long-acting insulins (e.g., glargine insulin, NPH insulin) should be started initially. Rapid-acting insulins (e.g., lispro) are added to basal insulin regimens when glycemic control is not achieved with basal insulin alone.

C) CORRECT:

An increased urine albumin:creatinine ratio (UACR) indicates albuminuria (UACR of 30–300 mg/g indicates microalbuminuria). While all first-line antihypertensive agents are appropriate for adults with diabetes and hypertension, an ACE inhibitor (ACEI) or an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) is the antihypertensive of choice if the patient has albuminuria as these drugs have been shown to have a renoprotective effect in this patient group. The blood pressure target should be individualized; for patients with a high 10-year ASCVD risk, < 130/80 mm Hg is an appropriate treatment goal if safely attained. The American Diabetes Association also recommends prescribing SGLT-2 inhibitors for renoprotection in patients with albuminuria.

In addition to lifestyle modifications, metformin, an ACEI (or ARB), and an SGLT-2 inhibitor, this patient should also be initiated on statin therapy, which is indicated in all patients aged 40–75 years with diabetes mellitus, regardless of lipid levels.

Additionally, a short course of basal insulin therapy should be considered for patients with symptomatic hyperglycemia (as seen here), signs of a continued catabolic state (e.g., weight loss), initial glucose ≥ 300 mg/dL, or HbA1c > 10%.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspirin therapy should be considered for the primary prevention of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) in patients 40–59 years of age with a high 10-year ASCVD risk (≥ 10%) and a low risk of bleeding. In patients > 60 years of age, aspirin is not recommended for the primary prevention of ASCVD.

E) INCORRECT:

Given this patient's comorbidities, additional management besides lifestyle modifications and monotherapy with metformin is required.
questions.hint: Random plasma glucose ≥ 200 mg/dL in a patient with symptoms of hyperglycemia (i.e., fatigue, polyuria, polydipsia, blurred vision) is consistent with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM). Comorbidities are common in patients with T2DM and should be addressed.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of fatigue, polyuria, and blurry vision. BMI is 28 kg/m2 and blood pressure is 147/95 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 192 mg/dL and hemoglobin A1c concentration of 7.2%. Urinalysis shows 1+ glucose, 1+ protein, and no ketones. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management to prevent cardiovascular disease in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Early antihypertensive treatment is recommended in diabetic patients to prevent cardiovascular disease (diabetic nephropathy and retinopathy). The target blood pressure is generally considered to be < 130/80 mm Hg in patients with diabetes mellitus. All first-line antihypertensive agents are effective in adults with diabetes. However, in the presence of microalbuminuria, ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril or angiotensin receptor blockers are the treatment of choice, as they are the only agents that prevent progression of microalbuminuria and renal tubulointerstitial fibrosis.

In addition to antihypertensive and nephroprotective therapy, lifestyle changes (regular exercise, diet modification, weight loss) should be encouraged and an oral anti-diabetic agent should be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Bariatric surgery (e.g., sleeve gastrectomy) is indicated for patients with a BMI ≥ 35, those with a BMI ≥ 30 and type 2 diabetes mellitus, or individuals with a BMI of 30–34.9 who do not achieve significant weight loss with nonsurgical methods. Since weight loss or stabilization greatly improves the prognosis in patients with type 2 diabetes, dietary changes should be recommended to this patient, but surgery is not indicated at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Aspirin therapy is recommended as secondary prophylaxis in all patients with diabetes mellitus and cardiovascular disease (e.g., stroke, myocardial infarction). This therapy may also be considered as primary prophylaxis in individuals ≥ 50 years with diabetes mellitus and at least one additional major cardiovascular risk factor (e.g., family history of premature ASCVD, dyslipidemia, hypertension). There is insufficient evidence to recommend aspirin in individuals < 50 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient most likely has type 2 diabetes, which should initially be treated with oral antidiabetic drugs (e.g., metformin). Insulin should only be considered if monotherapy or dual-therapy with oral antidiabetic drugs does not sufficiently control blood glucose levels.

E) INCORRECT:

Individuals with diabetes should undergo annual serum lipid panel monitoring and those 40–75 years of age with cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., smoking, high cholesterol, hypertension, obesity) should be started on lipid-lowering treatment. However, statins (e.g., atorvastatin, pravastatin, simvastatin) are considered first-line and are preferred over fibrates (e.g., gemfibrozil), which are considered a second-line treatment for hypercholesterolemia.
questions.hint: In a symptomatic patient, a single measurement of hemoglobin A1c > 6.5% is diagnostic of diabetes mellitus. The presence of protein in the urine suggests early microvascular disease due to diabetes mellitus.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents for a routine follow-up. He has a 7-year history of type 1 diabetes mellitus managed with multiple daily insulin injections. His last hemoglobin A1c was 7.4% (reference <7.0%). He has no complaints of polyuria, weight loss, or fatigue, and reports no episodes of hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia. He has no known microvascular or macrovascular complications (see lab results).

Blood pressure
118/72 mmHg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
80 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Urine




 Albumin-to-creatinine ratio
45 mg/g
< 30 mg/g



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intensify insulin therapy to lower hemoglobin A1c below 6.5%
Repeat urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio in 12 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While optimal glycemic control is crucial in type 1 diabetes, this patient's hemoglobin A1c of 7.4% is only slightly above target, and he has no symptoms or glycemic extremes. His albumin-to-creatinine ratio indicates early renal involvement. Intensifying insulin may not provide additional renal benefit and could increase hypoglycemia risk. Renoprotective strategies are more beneficial in this context.

B) INCORRECT:

Repeating the urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio annually is appropriate for normal findings. However, this patient has microalbuminuria, necessitating sooner confirmatory testing within 3 to 6 months. Prompt re-evaluation allows for timely intervention with renoprotective strategies to slow renal progression.

C) CORRECT:

In patients with type 1 diabetes, microalbuminuria is an early indicator of diabetic nephropathy. An albumin-to-creatinine ratio of 45 mg/g suggests mild renal endothelial dysfunction. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors reduce intraglomerular pressure and proteinuria, slowing nephropathy progression even with normal blood pressure. Their renoprotective effects make them essential in managing early diabetic kidney disease.

Key learning point: In asymptomatic patients with type I diabetes mellitus, ACE inhibitors are recommended for renal protection and prevention of diabetic nephropathy, even in the absence of hypertension.

D) INCORRECT:

Screening for diabetic nephropathy in type 1 diabetes primarily uses the spot urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio. This patient already has elevated levels indicating microalbuminuria. A 24-hour urine test for total protein is more useful for overt proteinuria or nephrotic syndrome and is less convenient and sensitive for early diabetic kidney disease.

questions.text: A 58-year-old with type 2 diabetes and persistent albuminuria presents for follow-up. Which step best slows further kidney damage?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) are essential in managing diabetic nephropathy by blocking angiotensin II type 1 receptors. This action reduces efferent arteriole constriction, lowering intraglomerular pressure and proteinuria. By decreasing glomerular capillary pressure, ARBs help prevent mesangial expansion and fibrosis, directly addressing the pathophysiological mechanisms of renal injury in patients with persistent albuminuria.

Key learning point: Proteinuria is a key indicator of diabetic nephropathy in patients with type 2 diabetes, reflecting kidney damage and increased permeability of the glomerular filtration barrier.

B) INCORRECT:

Increasing dietary protein intake in diabetic nephropathy can exacerbate glomerular hyperfiltration and intraglomerular pressure, accelerating nephron damage. High protein diets are linked to faster renal function decline, contrasting with protein restriction strategies that mitigate renal injury.

C) INCORRECT:

Statin therapy reduces cardiovascular risk in type 2 diabetes by lowering LDL cholesterol. However, it does not directly address the intraglomerular hypertension and protein leakage associated with diabetic nephropathy. Statins have limited evidence for reducing proteinuria or slowing renal function decline in this context.

D) INCORRECT:

Loop diuretics promote natriuresis and diuresis by inhibiting the Na+/K+/2Cl– cotransporter, managing fluid overload. However, they do not address the glomerular hyperfiltration and increased intraglomerular pressure in diabetic nephropathy, which are best managed by agents affecting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to your clinic because of frequent urination. For the past year, she has been urinating multiple times per hour and reports increased thirst and hunger. She denies dysuria. She does not exercise due to a demanding job, and her diet mainly consists of pizza and cheeseburgers. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination is normal. Her blood glucose level today is 11.1 mmol/L (4.0–11.0) and her hemoglobin A1C is 7.4% (4.8%–6.0%). Urinalysis shows microalbuminuria. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of her proteinuria?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diffuse glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules) is a characteristic finding of diabetic nephropathy that occurs in later stages of the disease, following glomerular basement membrane thickening and a period of mesangial expansion due to chronic hyperglycemia, hyperlipidemia, elevated levels of growth hormones, and intraglomerular hypertension. However, the recent onset of this patient's symptoms in the past year and the fact that microalbuminuria is the earliest sign of diabetic nephropathy make diffuse nodular glomerulosclerosis unlikely at this point.

B) INCORRECT:

Continuous activation of complement C3 is the underlying cause of membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type II (MPGN 2), which can manifest with proteinuria in severe cases. However, when proteinuria is present, excreted levels are typically in the nephrotic range (≥ 3.5 g/day) and accompanied by manifestations of nephrotic syndrome (e.g., edema, hypoproteinemia, hyperlipidemia). Furthermore, nephritic syndrome is more common in MPGN 2. Mixed nephritic-nephrotic syndrome can also occasionally occur.

C) INCORRECT:

Renal papillary necrosis leads to proteinuria and may be associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus. However, renal papillary necrosis is accompanied by tubular proteinuria (i.e., the excretion of lower molecular weight proteins) rather than the excretion of albumin, which indicates glomerular damage. Furthermore, gross hematuria would be expected in renal papillary necrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Functional deficits in type IV collagen are seen in Alport syndrome (characterized by a structural mutation of collagen) and Goodpasture syndrome (in which an autoantibody against collagen is present). In both conditions, patients usually present with nephritic syndrome. Hallmark symptoms include hematuria and hypertension. On urinalysis, dysmorphic RBCs, as well as RBC casts, are seen. In Alport syndrome, patients also present with bilateral hearing loss.

E) CORRECT:

Increased glomerular filtration is the underlying cause of proteinuria. Increased glomerular filtration is caused by glycation, which results from chronic hyperglycemia. Glycation causes increased permeability and thickening of the basement membrane, thereby leading to urinary excretion of albumin. Glycation also increases the rigidity of the efferent glomerular arterioles, which accelerates hyperfiltration and mesangial expansion and causes progressive loss of glomerular function. This chronic degenerative process can be monitored by measuring urine albumin levels.

Microalbuminuria (urine albumin levels of 30–300 mg/day) is the earliest sign of diabetic nephropathy. ACE inhibitors, which have a protective effect against renal tubulointerstitial fibrosis and prevent the progression of albuminuria, are the first-line antihypertensive treatment for patients with diabetes.

Key learning point: In early diabetic nephropathy, chronic hyperglycemia leads to increased glomerular filtration and basement membrane permeability, resulting in microalbuminuria as the earliest sign of glomerular damage.
questions.hint: This patient has symptoms and laboratory results that suggest diabetes mellitus. She has a hemoglobin A1C ≥ 6.5%, confirmed with a random blood glucose of 11.1 mmol/L, along with classic symptoms of hyperglycemia (polydipsia, polyphagia, polyuria).

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of fatigue and weakness. Her hemoglobin A1c was 13.5% (4.8%–6.0%) 12 weeks ago. Her blood pressure is 152/92 mm Hg. On examination, she has lower extremity edema. Serum studies show the following:


Potassium (K), blood
5.1 mmol/L (3.5–5.1)


Phosphate (PO4), blood
1.6 mmol/L (0.81–1.58)


Calcium (Ca), total, blood
1.95 mmol/L (2.12–2.52)


Urea, blood
21.4 mmol/L (2.1–8.0)


Creatinine, blood
194 μmol/L (49–93)


Which one of the following is the most appropriate parameter for early detection of her renal condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of urinary red blood cell casts indicates glomerulonephritis (GN). This finding is caused by the congregation of proteins and RBCs inside the tubules. Clinically, GN can result in red or cola-colored urine, mild edema (due to the relatively limited loss of albumin), and hypertension (i.e., nephritic syndrome). However, diabetic nephropathy classically leads to nephrotic syndrome, not nephritic syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

Microalbuminuria is the earliest diagnostic sign of diabetic nephropathy. Progression of glomerular damage (nodular glomerulosclerosis) leads to increased urinary loss of albumin, which can manifest as nephrotic syndrome. The extent of albuminuria in patients with diabetic nephropathy also correlates with the risk of future cardiovascular events. ACE inhibitors can prevent the progression of albuminuria in patients with diabetic nephropathy.

Key learning point: Microalbuminuria, detected by measuring urinary albumin, is the earliest diagnostic sign of diabetic nephropathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Serum urea nitrogen (BUN) is routinely measured as part of renal function testing in patients with diabetic nephropathy and other forms of chronic kidney disease. However, BUN is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only rises once the glomerular filtration rate significantly deteriorates.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum creatinine is routinely measured as part of renal function testing in patients with diabetic nephropathy and other forms of chronic kidney disease. However, it is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only rises once the glomerular filtration rate significantly deteriorates.

E) INCORRECT:

Diabetic nephropathy leads to nephrotic syndrome, which typically manifests with hypoproteinemia. However, total protein is usually normal in the early stages of diabetic nephropathy and only decreases once there is significant glomerular damage.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents with features of diabetic nephropathy (elevated creatinine and BUN levels, arterial hypertension, electrolyte abnormalities, edema).

questions.text:
A 64-year-old woman comes to your clinic for follow-up. She reports feeling well. She has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with metformin. A retinal examination 2 years ago showed mild nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy. She is 165 cm tall and weighs 54 kg; BMI is 20. Physical examination is normal. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), blood

8.4% (4.8%–6.0%)


Glucose, random, blood
10.6 mmol/L (4.0–11.0)


Urea, blood
7.9 mmol/L (2.1–8.0)


Creatinine, blood
97 μmol/L (49–93)


Urinalysis
2+ protein and increased urinary albumin excretion



Which one of the following is most likely responsible for the initiation of her renal disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hyperinsulinemia occurs early in the course of type 2 diabetes mellitus as a result of insulin resistance. Although hyperinsulinemia may lead to renal damage via several mechanisms, it is not the most significant risk factor for the initiation of DN, since DN also occurs in type 1 diabetes mellitus in which patients are hypoinsulinemic.

B) INCORRECT:

Glycosuria occurs in patients with diabetes mellitus when blood glucose levels exceed renal tubular reabsorption capacity (typically when blood glucose levels are above 10 mmol/L). While glycosuria is an important risk factor for urinary tract infections, it is not associated with the initiation or progression of DN.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperreninemia plays a significant role as the initiator of pathological renal changes in hypertensive nephropathy. In DN, paracrine hyperreninemia and RAAS activation (secondary to altered glomerular structure and hemodynamics) lead to a vicious cycle that contributes to the progression of DN. Therefore, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers, which have a renoprotective effect independent of the degree of blood-pressure reduction, are used to limit the progression of DN. However, the role of hyperreninemia in the initiation of DN is less clear; normotensive patients with diabetes mellitus often have low or normal levels of plasma renin activity prior to the onset of DN. A different pathophysiological process is the primary initiator of glomerular changes of DN.

D) CORRECT:

Hyperglycemia is the most significant risk factor for the initiation and progression of DN. Nonenzymatic glycation of proteins occurs in a hyperglycemic environment and results in the formation of advanced glycation end-products and reactive oxygen species, which activate intercellular signaling pathways that lead to epigenetic alterations of proinflammatory and profibrotic gene expression. In the kidneys, this process manifests with thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, progressive glomerular hypertrophy, and glomerulosclerosis, resulting in worsening of the filtration capacity and possibly end-stage renal disease. Glycemic control early in the course of diabetes mellitus has been shown to limit the initiation and progression of DN independent of glycemic control later on (legacy effect). Stringent glycemic control may even partially reverse the loss of glomerular function.

Key learning point: Chronic hyperglycemia is the primary risk factor for the initiation and progression of diabetic nephropathy due to nonenzymatic glycation and resulting glomerular damage.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a kidney autopsy specimen (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

Nodular glomerulosclerosis in diabetic nephropathy (Kimmelstiel-Wilson syndrome) displays with mesangial thickening due to nodular, hyaline deposits (Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions; yellow overlay) within the glomerulus (blue overlay). Further findings include thickening of the tubular basement membranes, tubular atrophy, and an increase of interstitial connective tissue between renal tubules (interstitial fibrosis).

Nodular glomerulosclerosis takes a decade or longer to develop in diabetes mellitus.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

E) INCORRECT:

Albuminuria is an early sign of DN and is used as a clinical marker to detect the onset and grade the severity of DN. However, the filtered albumin does not lead to glomerular damage, and albuminuria occurs only when the glomerular filtration capacity is already impaired.
questions.hint: Proteinuria with increased urinary albumin excretion in a patient with long-standing type 2 diabetes mellitus is suggestive of diabetic nephropathy (DN).

Screening for albuminuria is crucial for identifying diabetic nephropathy early and is recommended for three groups: patients who have had type 1 diabetes for at least 5 years, patients who have type 1 diabetes and comorbid hypertension, and all patients with type 2 diabetes. The best screening test for diabetic nephropathy is a spot urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio. Both moderate and severe albuminuria (defined by a urinary albumin excretion of 30 to 300 mg/day and > 300 mg/day, respectively) are associated with a decline in kidney function and increased mortality. Early recognition of albuminuria may prompt a change in care or the addition of an agent to block the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone axis.

Urine albumin is a more sensitive marker for diabetic kidney disease than urine protein. The urine albumin test is performed as an immunoassay and can detect minute amounts of urine albumin that are above the threshold for normal but below the threshold for the urinary dipstick. This test also includes the urine creatinine level to account for whether the specimen is concentrated or dilute.

Key learning point: A sensitive screening test for detecting early diabetic kidney disease is the measurement of urine albumin.

E) INCORRECT:

Although dipstick urinalysis can detect urine protein, it is not recommended as a screening test in this clinical context because it is not sufficiently sensitive to detect the low urine protein concentrations seen in patients with early diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of fatigue, polyuria, and blurry vision. His BMI is 28 and blood pressure is 147/95 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 10.7 mmol/L (4.0–6.0) and hemoglobin A1c concentration of 7.2% (4.8%–6.0%). Urinalysis shows 1+ glucose, 1+ protein, and no ketones. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management to prevent cardiovascular disease in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aspirin therapy is recommended as secondary prophylaxis in all patients with diabetes mellitus and cardiovascular disease (e.g., stroke, myocardial infarction). Routine use of aspirin for primary prophylaxis for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease is not recommended in Canada, regardless of sex, age, or diabetes status.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient most likely has type 2 diabetes, which should initially be treated with oral antidiabetic drugs (e.g., metformin). Insulin should only be considered if monotherapy or dual-therapy with oral antidiabetic drugs does not sufficiently control blood glucose levels.

C) CORRECT:

Early antihypertensive treatment is recommended in diabetic patients to prevent cardiovascular disease (diabetic nephropathy and retinopathy). The target blood pressure is generally considered to be < 130/80 mm Hg in patients with diabetes mellitus. All first-line antihypertensive agents are effective in adults with diabetes. However, in the presence of microalbuminuria, ACE inhibitors such as lisinopril or angiotensin receptor blockers are the treatment of choice, as they are the only agents that prevent progression of microalbuminuria and renal tubulointerstitial fibrosis.

In addition to antihypertensive and nephroprotective therapy, lifestyle changes (regular exercise, diet modification, weight loss) should be encouraged and an oral anti-diabetic agent should be considered.

Key learning point: ACE inhibitors or ARBs are first-line antihypertensive agents in diabetic patients with proteinuria, as they reduce blood pressure and help prevent progression of diabetic nephropathy and cardiovascular disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Individuals with diabetes should undergo annual serum lipid panel monitoring and those 40–75 years of age with cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., smoking, high cholesterol, hypertension, obesity) should be started on lipid-lowering treatment. However, statins (e.g., atorvastatin, pravastatin, simvastatin) are considered first-line and are preferred over fibrates (e.g., gemfibrozil), which are considered a second-line treatment for hypercholesterolemia.

E) INCORRECT:

Bariatric surgery (e.g., sleeve gastrectomy) is indicated for patients with a BMI ≥ 35, those with a BMI ≥ 30 and type 2 diabetes mellitus, or individuals with a BMI of 30–34.9 who do not achieve significant weight loss with nonsurgical methods. Since weight loss or stabilization greatly improves the prognosis in patients with type 2 diabetes, dietary changes should be recommended to this patient, but surgery is not indicated at this time.
questions.hint: In a symptomatic patient, a single measurement of hemoglobin A1c ≥ 6.5% is diagnostic of diabetes mellitus. The presence of protein in the urine suggests early microvascular disease due to diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension presents to the emergency department for a tetanus booster after scratching his hand on a rusty nail while gardening. He feels well and has no other complaints. His current treatment is metformin 500 mg twice daily and hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg once daily. Routine screening laboratories obtained as part of his evaluation show creatinine 1.5 mg/dL (previously 1.2 mg/dL), estimated GFR 54 mL/min/1.73 m², and a urine dipstick positive for protein. Urine microscopy shows no hematuria or casts. Vital signs are BP, 154/92 mm Hg; P, 76; R, 16; T, 36.9°C (98.4°F). He has received appropriate tetanus prophylaxis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate intensive insulin therapy to achieve an HbA1c below 6.0%
Initiate an ACE inhibitor and double the metformin dose
Start an SGLT2 inhibitor and double the dose of hydrochlorothiazide
Recommend repeat testing of renal function in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although glycemic control is important, aggressive glucose lowering increases the risk of hypoglycemia. Moderate control (A1c 6.5–8%) alongside renoprotective therapy is safer and more effective for slowing disease progression.

B) INCORRECT:

While blood pressure control is essential, calcium channel blockers do not lower intraglomerular pressure or reduce proteinuria as effectively as ACE inhibitors or ARBs. They are considered adjunctive agents, not first-line renoprotective therapy.

C) CORRECT:

Correct — Persistent proteinuria with declining GFR in a patient with diabetes indicates diabetic kidney disease. The next step is to initiate an ACE inhibitor (or ARB) to reduce intraglomerular pressure and albuminuria, slowing disease progression. Glycemic control should also be optimized; in this patient, increasing metformin to 1,000 mg twice daily may be appropriate, provided renal function remains stable (eGFR >45 mL/min/1.73 m²) and gastrointestinal tolerance allows. Both interventions are evidence-based strategies that mitigate further microvascular injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Although SGLT2 inhibitors can provide renal and cardiovascular benefits in diabetes, they should complement, not replace, ACE inhibitor or ARB therapy. Increasing the thiazide dose in a patient with diabetic kidney disease may worsen volume depletion and reduce renal perfusion, accelerating GFR decline.

E) INCORRECT:

Even mild reductions in GFR with persistent proteinuria signify early diabetic nephropathy and require intervention.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with a 9-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents for routine follow-up in the Outpatient Clinic. He has no acute complaints but reports occasionally waking at night to urinate. He denies recent infections, NSAID use, intense exercise, new medication changes, or episodes of hypotension in the last three months. Physical examination is normal, with normal blood pressure and no peripheral edema (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Glucose, fasting
7.6 mmol/L
3.5 - 6.5 mmol/L


Creatinine
92 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Urine




 Spot urine albumin/creatinine ratio
34 mg/g
< 30 mg/g 



What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order a 24-hour urine protein excretion test
Repeat the spot urine albumin/creatinine ratio

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The spot urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio is a reliable method for detecting microalbuminuria in diabetic patients, making a 24-hour urine collection unnecessary. The patient's spot ACR of 34 mg/g indicates microalbuminuria. The spot ACR is less burdensome and minimizes collection errors, making it preferable for monitoring renal status in type 2 diabetes mellitus.

B) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors are beneficial for diabetic patients with confirmed persistent microalbuminuria. However, the patient's spot urine albumin/creatinine ratio is only mildly elevated at 34 mg/g. A single measurement may be influenced by transient factors, so repeating the test is advised to confirm persistent microalbuminuria before starting treatment.

C) CORRECT:

Microalbuminuria, an early indicator of diabetic nephropathy, reflects subtle glomerular injury due to chronic hyperglycemia. The spot urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio standardizes albumin excretion, reducing variability. Factors like exercise or transient hemodynamic changes can temporarily elevate urinary albumin. Guidelines recommend repeating the test, ideally from a first-morning void, to confirm persistent microalbuminuria before initiating interventions like renoprotective agents. This ensures management decisions are based on a reliable abnormality in albumin excretion.

Key learning point: In patients with diabetes and newly detected microalbuminuria, the first step is to confirm the finding by repeating the urine albumin/creatinine ratio to rule out transient causes.

D) INCORRECT:

Renal ultrasound assesses structural abnormalities like hydronephrosis. However, this patient is asymptomatic with normal creatinine levels and mildly elevated urine albumin/creatinine ratio, suggesting early diabetic renal changes rather than structural anomalies. Ultrasound is indicated for suspected obstructive uropathy or anatomical abnormalities, which are not suggested here.
